dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZEV, 90, opens his effervescent blue eyes with a shudder. He is drenched in sweat. He was having a bad dream. His eyes, a valley surrounded by deep mountainous wrinkles, attempt to adjust to the dim light. With an aged, deep voice, bearing thick traces of an Eastern European accent the old man mutters a half question:

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Ruth? Zev slowly turns his head to the right, expecting to find his wife. However, nobody is there. He strains his eyes at the slightly creased pillow and tucked in sheet, trying to get a grasp on the situation. After a moment, he sits up and stares ahead at a mirror. Instead of seeing his aged reflection though, he looks at white sheet. This room has been prepared for sitting shiv - the Jewish tradition of mourning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PIANO takes up a quarter of the small room. Like in the bedroom, the mirrors are covered with white sheets. PAULA, black, 40s, heavyset, Senegalese, knits a sweater worn-in, reclining chair.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Where is my wife? Paula is startled, but it is Zev -- standing timidly in t bedroom doorway -- who is afraid.

dialogues.speaker: PAULA
dialogues.text: Mr. Guttman! You can’t be sneaking up on me like that!

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Where is my wife? Where is Ruth? Paula stands with a truly sympathetic look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: PAULA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mr. Guttman. Your wife passed away about a week ago. Zev takes in this devastating information. Dead? A week ago? Zev takes a seat on the piano bench and begins to ru his forehead with his arthritic hands. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: PAULA
dialogues.text: My name’s Paula. I was Mrs. Guttman’s nursing aide. Your family asked me to help out for another week or two.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: (meekly) I'm... a little confused.

dialogues.speaker: PAULA
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Mr. Guttman. You’ve been through a lot the last week. Paula gives Zev the most compassionate smile she can muster, despite this being a conversation she’s probably had before. Zev looks around the apartment as if he’s a visitor and not the tenant.

dialogues.speaker: PAULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s get some breakfast. You've been feeling better after breakfast. Paula approaches Zev and takes his hand. He’s as lost as little child who’s been separated from his parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are few places in the world as sterile as the hallways of a senior housing community. The olive green, diamond patterned carpet has been vacuumed every day. The fluorescent overhead lights are without a trace of dust. The flowers on wooden tables by the elevator banks are as fake as the lithographs hanging above them. Zev and Paula exit the apartment. Zev walks with a slight shuffle but is more than able to get around by himself. CELE, nonagenarian, walks toward Zev, pushing a walker wi tennis balls attached to the bottom. She smiles at him as she gets closer.

dialogues.speaker: CELE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Zev.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Good morning. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: CELE
dialogues.text: I hope you’re not too hungry. Breakfast is crummy as usual.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: That’s okay. I’m not too hungry. Cele continues her journey down the hallway. Zev gives he a second look. When Cele’s out of earshot, Paula whispers

dialogues.speaker: PAULA
dialogues.text: That’s Cele. She was friends with your wife.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: (irritated) I know who she is. Like most people suffering from dementia, it’s very easy for Zev to become irritated and suffer mood swings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev and Paula sit at a long rectangular table, eating breakfast. The eggs, toast and fruit are separated on a compartmentalized plastic dish on an orange plastic tray. Most of the SENIORS in the cafeteria, like Zev, reside in INDEPENDENT LIVING WING of the senior housing community. However, there are others who require full time CARETAKER and reside in the ASSISTED LIVING WING. MAX, a feeble old man in a wheelchair, is one such man. H gets pushed up to the table by his AIDE. Max is on the opposite side of the spectrum as Zev; his body has gone t hell but his brain is extremely acute. There’s an oxygen tank attached to Max’s wheelchair. The necessity of it is quickly apparent as he struggles to breathe as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Can you -- give us -- a minute? Max, like Zev, enunciates every word when he speaks -- an indication that English is their second language.

dialogues.speaker: PAULA
dialogues.text: No problem, Max. Zev shoots Paula an angry look with his piercing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: You don’t need to tell me everyone’s name. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paula and Max’s aide gossip in their native tongue as the walk away. Max looks around to make sure the coast is cle

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Tonight is the last night -- sitting shiva for Ruth. (long breath) Do you remember -- what you said - - you would do? (long breath) What you said -- you would do -- when Ruth died. Zev thinks about it but comes up blank.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: No. Zev shakes his head in frustration. Max gathers his breat

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: It’s okay. (long breath) I wrote everything down -- so you could remember. Max pats his jacket pocket, as if something is inside. He then starts to cough uncontrollably. His aide walks over and inserts the oxygen nose-clip into Max’s nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: MAX'S AIDE
dialogues.text: Come on, Mr. Rosenbaum. Time for a nap. The aide takes Max away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MINYAN is gathered. It’s a big crowd for a small apartment. ZEV’S CHILDREN, GRANDCHILDREN, GREAT GRANDCHILDREN and FRIENDS are all present and being led through the prayers by a RABBI. Zev wears black slacks, a white button down shirt and an old tweed professor’s blazer with patches on the elbows. is also the only one without their Siddur opened; this is not a man who believes in god. The adults -- sans Zev -- recite KADDISH. They’ve all got the prayer committed to memory. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: MINYAN
dialogues.text: Yit'gadal v'yit'kadash sh'mei raba. B'al'ma di v'ra khir'utei. V'yam'likh mal'khutei B'chayeikhon uv'yomeikhon uv'chayei d'khol beit yis'ra'eil ba'agala uviz'man kariv v'im'ru. Amein...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minyan is winding down. Family and friends finish the bagels and lox and say their goodbyes. Zev sits on the couch, receiving words of condolence as people make their way out of the apartment. His GREAT GRANDDAUGHTER, 8, sits next to him. Max gets wheeled up to the great granddaughter.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Do you know -- when that picture - - was taken? Max shakily points at a BLACK AND WHITE WEDDING PHOTOGRAP of Zev and RUTH, 20, beautiful. The photo stands on an en table, amongst family portraits. The great granddaughter shakes her head no. Max looks at Zev, who also doesn’t seem to have a clue.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That is from -- their wedding day -- in 1946.

dialogues.speaker: GREAT GRANDDAUGHTER
dialogues.text: Did you meet Nanny in Germany? There’s recognition in Zev’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: No. I met her in America. I met her at Coney Island. The great granddaughter looks transfixed at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: She was beautiful, -- wasn’t she? (off her nod) Why don’t you -- show the picture -- to your brother? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The great granddaughter excitedly takes the picture and w across the room to her brother ADAM, who stands next to t MOTHER and FATHER. Zev watches her cross the room with pr in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GREAT GRANDDAUGHTER
dialogues.text: Adam, look at this! As soon as she’s gone, Max slowly reaches into his coat pocket and pulls out an envelope. Zev’s name is written across it. Max’s hands shake almost uncontrollably as he gives the envelope to Zev as slyly as possible. Zev looks it, confused.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Now stand up -- tell everyone -- you're tired -- and go read it. Zev follows Max's orders. He rises from the couch and announces to the room...

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I am tired. I am going to bed now. CHARLES, 60s, Zev’s son, approaches and gently helps his to the bedroom. It’s only a small gesture but you can see much he loves his father.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Dad. It’s been a long week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev sits down on the bed and stares at the envelope. He o it and pulls out A STACK OF HUNDRED DOLLAR BILLS. Even if had control of all his faculties, he'd still be bewildere Zev then pulls out a TICKET and a THICK STAPLED LETTER, w he begins to read. He does not read it out loud but the p of the words are clear by the look on his face. After a beat, he stands up and walks to his closet. He be down and retrieves a small, black TOILETRY BAG...

dialogues.text: Zev exits his bedroom, carrying only the toiletry bag. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 13 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He shuffles across the room and lets himself out the fron door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev walks down the dark, silent hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev walks toward the lobby. As he gets closer, the glimmering light of security monitors rise from behind th front desk. However, the desk is vacated, with only a guard’s jacket draped over an empty chair. Zev walks past the desk, glances at the monitors and proceeds through the front doors, which gently slide open

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev stares into the pitch black parking lot. An early fal breeze blows, sending a slight chill down his spine. Afte a beat, a TAXI pulls up and Zev gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TAXI DRIVER already knows where Zev is going...

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: Penn Station, right?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: Max peers through his bedroom window as the taxi takes of and disappears into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, wearing pajamas, sitting in his wheelchair, watches the taillights fade away. After a beat...

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Got it. (MORE)

dialogues.text: The bedroom door opens behind Max; kneeling there is the jacket-less SECURITY GUARD, holding a PUSH PIN. Max’s aid hurries into the room with a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: MAX'S AIDE
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Mr. Rosenbaum. I don’t know how the door got locked.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Max turns from the window and looks at the security guard

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.text: 49 Lake Shore Limited! Last call! 49 Lake Shore Limited! Last call! Zev wipes off his sweaty forehead, gathers his courage, a steps onboard.

dialogues.text: We voyeuristically watch through the train’s windows as Z makes his way down the aisle and finds his assigned seat. then takes out the letter and begins to read it again. Af a beat, he removes a pen from his blazer and crosses something off the page.

dialogues.text: TYLER, 12, shaggy hair, plops down in the seat next to Ze He immediately looks out the window and waves at his MOTHER, late 30s.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Is that your mother?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: You're traveling alone?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: No, I’m with my brothers. They're sitting over there. Tyler points across the aisle at his OLDER BROTHERS.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Are you going to Cleveland too?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Why don’t you fly? It’s faster.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: That’s not a good reason. Zev laughs for the first time. Mood swings.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: You're a real whipper snapper, aren’t you? Why don’t you fly to Cleveland?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Three plane tickets is too expensive. That’s what my mom and dad said.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: That is a good reason. (beat) I am not flying because my friend told me to take the train in the letter he wrote me. Zev motions at the letter as he folds it up and places it his blazer’s inside pocket.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: See, that’s a good reason. (beat) My name’s Tyler. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 18 19 20 21 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 12

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Tyler. My name’s Zev.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: That’s a strange name.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: It means “wolf” in Hebrew.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Cool. I wish I had an animal name. Zev smiles at Tyler as the train’s engine begins to rumbl

ZEV’S APARTMENT - DAY 20 Paula sits on the reclining chair, knitting her sweater; she’s made considerable progress since yesterday morning. checks her watch and then KNOCKS on Zev’s bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: PAULA
dialogues.text: Mr. Guttman, time to wake up. (beat) It’s breakfast time. Paula knocks again and then opens the door. INT. ZEV’S BEDROOM - DAY - CONTINUOUS 21 The room is empty.

dialogues.speaker: PAULA
dialogues.text: Mr. Guttman? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PAULA, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: The DIRECTOR, 50s, wearing a suit and tie, sits across fr Charles and REBECCA, Zev’s daughter-in-law. Charles stirs his seat.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: We've notified the police and they've issued a silver alert anda reverse 9-1-1 for the community. Our staff is doing all we can--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I don’t understand how this could happen? Charles stands and paces the room, anger percolating. Bet the death of his mom and now this, it’s a lot to deal wit

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you how sorry we are. We try our best to keep an eye on everybody but--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: We pay you to do more than try your best.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Is there anything we can do to help?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Besides paying you to lose people?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Does your father have a credit card? (off Rebecca’s nod) You can tell the company to call you if he uses it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: We'll get right on that. The director takes a breath, ready to deliver even harder news. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Your mother’s nursing aid told me your dad’s been very confused recently. (MORE ) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 14

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She said he’s been having a hard time remembering people’s names and what day of the week it is--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: He has dementia. That’s why we moved my parents here.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: I know this isn’t easy to hear but it’s very common following the death of a spouse for more signs of neurocognitive disorders to emerge. Have you noticed that your father’s been having mood swings? Or that he rarely plays the piano anymore? This floats in the air. Rebecca turns to Charles.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I’ve noticed a few things, Charles. We were just so busy with your mom that I guess I dismissed them. Charles sits back down, the truth weighing on him. He run his hands through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Me too. Rebecca reaches out and holds Charles’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: When we find your father we’re going to need to reassess his living situation as he may require the more supervised environment of our assisted living wing. Charles and Rebecca nod their understanding.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: I'm entering your information into the FBI background check database.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: What do they look for?

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: A bunch of stuff. Whether you’re a convicted felon. Been involved in a crime of violence. If you’ve been dishonorably discharged from the army. If you’re mentally competent. If you’ve been convicted of more than one DUI within the last five years. If you’re a fugitive or currently charged with a felony.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: A fugitive?

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: If you’re running from the law. Zev half grins.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Do I look like I can run? The owner submits the information online. A throbber appe on the screen and starts to circle, processing Zev's information in the NICS database. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Let me show you some of our smaller handguns. The owner gives Zev the quick run down on guns, while pointing at them through the display case.

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We got everything from Sig Sauers to 1911’s to Glocks to single actions to double actions. (beat) You know much about guns?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: I would have guessed that but we get all types in here. The owner pulls out a Smith & Wesson 22.

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A lot of beginners go with a 22. It’s light. Easy to use. Very little recoil.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: That's what my friend suggested.

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: In my opinion though, you might as well buy a BB gun if you’re gonna go with a 22. Frankly, it’s just not gonna get the job done in an emergency. I’m not trying to give you the hard sell but for about five hundred more you could get something with real stopping power. The owner takes out a GLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a 9mm Glock 17.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Glock? Is it German?

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: You're in the right neighborhood. It’s manufactured in Austria. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 30 (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the most popular law enforcement pistol in the world. It’s only got a little bit of recoil so it shouldn’t hurt your hand but it’1ll definitely hurt an intruder. The owner hands the gun to Zev. He stares at it, not knowing exactly what to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK OF THE STORE
dialogues.text: We watch Zev from the end of an aisle of hunting gear.

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: 22 30 The owner glances at the computer. The throbber still spi

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm definitely biased toward Glocks. I just gave one to my girlfriend for our anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Is it easy to use?

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Simple.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Can you please write down the instructions for me?

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Sure thing. I can show you how to use it too.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: That would be good. But please write it down for me. Sometimes I forget things.

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: We all do. That’s no problem. The owner looks at the computer screen. Zev’s been approv by the NICS E-check system. It’s that easy.

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, you're good to go. Are you a veteran? Zev has to think about this for a second. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: GUN SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: We offer a veteran’s discount.  REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLERK, 40s, Indian, sits behind the desk, surfing the internet. Through the front glass doors we can see the to car pull up. Zev pays the driver with cash from the envel and then gets out of the car. After a beat, Zev enters the lobby with his toiletry bag a Buddy’s G & A shopping bag.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Mr. Guttman?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Your friend called before and said you'd be arriving soon. Your room's all ready for you. The clerk smiles and holds up the room key.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: How much do I owe?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: You can pay when you check-out. Oh, and I booked your taxi for the morning, like your friend asked.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is quiet with only faint sounds of a neighboring room’s television seeping through the walls. Slivers of n light beam through the cracks in the curtain. Zev lays on the bed, reading the letter. The empty box fo the Glock and a case of BULLETS is opened next to him. Th gun, fully loaded, sits on the bedside table. The phone RINGS. Zev answers it.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Hello? (beat) Yes, I’m okay. Thank you, Max. (beat) I will. Have a good night. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 24

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Zev hangs up the phone, folds the letter and places it under the Glock. He then stands and slowly begins to disrobe. In the room’s half light, traces of his once impressive physique can be seen. He removes his shirt and pants, carefully folding them with military precision. Besides his singlet and briefs, the only thing Zev wears a wedding ring and a gold, Star of David necklace. INT. BATHROOM —- NIGHT - MOMENTS LATER 33 Zev enters the bathroom. He sits down on the toilet seat and looks around the room. His eyes lock on the SPRINKLER on the ceiling; something about it bothers him. After a moment Zev shakes off the thought, puts down the drain in the tub and begins to draw a bath. As the water comes out, he lets out the slightest sigh of relief. With his left arm, he reaches out to test the water’s temperature revealing a small, crudely written, blue, CONCENTRATION CAMP TATTOO on his forearm. It reads: 98814 For survivors, a shower will always elicit fear, no matte how much time has passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev is sound asleep in the tub. If his skin wasn’t wrinkl from age, it would be now from sleeping in the bath. Zev's eyes open. He focuses on the white porcelain tub an tries to get his bearings. However, he doesn’t know north from south in this unfamiliar bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Ruth? (beat) Ruth?! Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the darkness of the hotel room, Zev, who has a towel wrapped around his waist, is a silhouette, backlit by the fluorescent bathroom lights emanating from behind him. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 36 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 25

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Ruth? Can you turn on the light? I can’t see. Ruth? Please. Please, Ruth. Silence. Zev brushes up against the wall, looking for a light switch. After a few seconds of flickering, a light turns on. Zev looks around the room, completely at a loss. He sees the Glock on the bedside table. This is the last thi he expected to see. He approaches the gun and carefully picks it up. He turns it over, examining it. He then notices the message on his left hand -- “Read Letter” -- and sees the envelope on th bed. He sits down, picks up the letter and begins to read After a beat, a tear streams down his cheek. He continues to read. After another moment he stops and LIFTS HIS LEFT ARM, examining his tattoo. He couldn’t possibly forget about that, could he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OHIO TAXI pulls up to the front of a two story, post- war, raised ranch style house, covered by aluminum siding Zev exits the taxi and slowly shuffles up the driveway; under his arm he carries his toiletry bag, the only place his Glock could be. The taxi waits in front. Zev holds a black metal railing as he climbs the house’s six front steps. As he gets closer, he can faintly hear t white noise of a VACUUM on the other side of the door. He takes a piece of paper out of his pocket, which has the name “Rudy Kurlander” written on it with the address of where he’s at. Zev rings the bell. While he waits for somebody to answer studies the paper. After a beat, he rings the bell again. Finally the vacuuming stops and the front door opens. A CLEANING LADY, 20s, stands there, armed with a Hoover.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Hello. Is Rudy Kurlander home?

dialogues.speaker: CLEANING LADY
dialogues.text: Yes. He’s downstairs. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 26

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The cleaning lady motions toward the dark stairs as she h the door open for Zev. Zev steps inside and begins to walk down, into the darkne After a few steps, the vacuum roars back to life behind h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev takes a moment to look at some PICTURES ON THE WALL. stares intensely at the OLD MAN in all of the photos. The sound of a television, mixed with a loud, deep belly laugh can be heard from the end of the hallway. Zev grasp his toiletry bag under his arm and walks toward the noise The television and laughter grow louder. Sweat starts to accumulate on Zev’s forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black and white episode of LAUREL AND HARDY plays on a plasma television. RUDY KURLANDER, 88, fat, sits on a wor in couch, enthralled by the TV.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Are you Rudy Kurlander? Rudy looks over and sees Zev standing in the shadows, HOLDING THE GLOCK at his side. The light from the TV flickers on Zev’s face.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: (composed) Yes, I am Rudy Kurlander. Who are you? Rudy speaks with a very thick Eastern European accent.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Please turn off the TV. Rudy turns off the TV. Without this light source, the roo is draped in darkness except for the slivers of light peering through the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Do I know you? Zev is trying to figure that out.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Please stand by the window. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 27

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I am not going to do anything until you tell me who you are and why you’re here.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Let us not argue. Please, stand by the window. Obediently, Rudy pushes himself up off the couch. He pick up his cane and walks five feet to the window.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I need to see light on your face. Rudy moves a few blinds to the side. A shard of bright light illuminates his eyes. He squints as the sunshine irritates his cataracts.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Turn your head.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Who are you?!

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Please, do not yell. (beat) Do as I say. Turn your head. Rudy turns his head, staring through the blinds at the Yellow Birches in the backyard. Zev studies the old man’s profile.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you German? After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Ja. Sind Sie Deutscher? Subtitle: “Yes. Are you German?"

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 28

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rudy talks more confidently in his native tongue. Zev understands the German but continues to speak in English.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Achtundachtzig. Subtitle: “Eighty eight."

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Were you in the German army? (off Rudy’s nod) What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Das liegt in der Vergangenheit. Subtitle: “It's in the past.” Zev shakes his head, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Please speak in English. I don’t like German. What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: It was almost seventy years ago. I was very young.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Answer the question. Rudy lets this process.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Are you a Jew?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) Were you at Auschwitz?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: We are too old for lies so please do not.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I am not lying. (beat) (MORE ) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: REMEMBER
dialogues.text: Double White Rev (08-15-14) 29

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I did not know about Auschwitz until after the war. (beat) I was in North Africa.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: North Africa?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I was with the Desert Fox. I was with Rommel. Zev tries to wrap his head around this.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Do you have proof?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Yes. Over there. Rudy points at the bar on the side of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Show it to me. Rudy walks behind the bar and, using his cane as a brace, slowly gets down on his knees -- this is not an easy task for an old man.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: When I became a U.S. citizen, the immigration officer asked me if I had ever associated with the Nazi government of Germany or if I worked at a concentration camp. (beat) I told the officer what I’1l tell you. Yes, I served for my country. I was a soldier. I was a proud German and that’s what the men did. I’m still proud of my service. Rudy removes some photo albums from a drawer behind the bar. RUDY (CONT’D) As far as the Jews. I did not care about the Jews. I thought Hitler was right. They caused many problems for the country. However, I was in North Africa. I thought we were deporting them or putting them in work camps...not what they did. (beat) (MORE ) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 30

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RUDY (CONT’D) That was shameful. But that was not me. Rudy finally pulls out a weathered album and takes it bac to the couch. He then motions for Zev to sit next to him. RUDY (CONT’D) Please. Zev sits down, still clutching the Glock. Rudy opens the album which has its fair share of dust on The pictures inside are sepia toned and frayed at the edg There’s also a few ribbons and medals tucked into the pag Rudy turns to a picture of his TANK UNIT in Libya and poi at A MAN WEARING A KNIGHT’S CROSS around his neck... RUDY (CONT’D) That’s Rommel. A proud smile forms on Rudy’s face. RUDY (CONT’D) History remembers the winners. Eisenhower, Patton, Montgomery... (shakes his head, dismissive) Rommel was the genius. A memory flashes across Rudy’s face. RUDY (CONT’D) One time my division was taking a rest, cleaning the tanks’ air filters from the sand and drinking our precious water when we saw Rommel’s Storch flying right at us. All of a sudden something dropped from the sky and knocked my canteen right out of my hand, spilling my water. It was a note, wrapped around a rock. I opened it and it said, “If you don’t move on at once I shall come down!” And he signed it -- Rommel. So we got back in our tanks and moved on. (beat) Nobody could lead like him. Rudy wipes drool off his lips with the back of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Can I have a glass of water? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 31

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rudy nods and closes the photo album.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I can use one too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sits in his wheelchair, staring out the window at the front parking lot. The phone RINGS and Max shakily picks up and holds it to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Is this Max?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: This is Zev.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I am in Ohio. (beat) It was not him. Max takes a few deep breaths through his oxygen nose-clip

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (OVER THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Then you must go on. (deep breath) You must find him. (deep breath) (MORE ) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 32

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must -- do what -- you said you would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev sits on a charter bus, staring out the window. He tak in the passing cars, rest stops, speed traps and motorcyclists as the bus travels through Ohio and Michiga 4l EXT. SAULT STE. MARIE, MICHIGAN - DAY 41 The bus slows down and merges with other vehicles into a single lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev puts down the letter -- which he’s reading for the hundredth time -- and watches in awe as the bus crosses t SAULT STE. MARIE INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE over St. Mary’s Riv It doesn't take long for the bus to reach the dividing li between America and Canada; the point is marked by each nation’s flag, waving in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROW BEHIND ZEV
dialogues.text: Through the crack between the chairs, we see Zev begin to reread the letter. After a beat, he takes off his blazer carefully folds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRAVELERS stand in line, slowly going through customs. Th process is orderly. There’s a system. The people are compliant, simply doing as they’re told. Despite not wearing his blazer, Zev’s sweating. He’s nerv His eyes dart back and forth from one red maple leaf to another. They seem to be everywhere. There’s flags hangin from poles, patches on CBSA OFFICERS’s uniforms, decals o the walls. The pageantry has him on edge.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER, (ON P.A. SYSTEM)
dialogues.text: Please have your documents ready. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 33

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Zev's eyes shoot up to the speakers on the wall. He wipes sweat from his brow and clutches his toiletry bag; we kno what’s in there. A CBSA AGENT walks by with a GERMAN SHEPHERD on a leash. Instinctively, Zev steps back. He’s scared of dogs.

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: Declaration card. (beat) Sir, can I have your declaration card? Zev looks up and sees CBSA OFFICER. He opens his toiletry and pulls out the letter and his DECLARATION CARD. He han the declaration card to the officer, who peruses it, maki sure it’s filled in properly. CBSA OFFICER (CONT’D) What’s the purpose of your trip?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I am visiting a friend. Thousands of people pass through this border crossing eve day, so these questions are rote for the officer.

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: What’s your friend’s name?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Rudy Kurlander.

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: Where does he live? Zev looks at the letter for the answer but butchers the pronunciation.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Foyer Des Pionniers--

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: Can I see that? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 34

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The officer holds out his hand for the letter. Zev acquiesces, slowly placing it right in his palm. The offi skims over the page. CBSA OFFICER (CONT’D) (in perfect French) Foyer Des Pionniers Nursing Home. The officer continues to look over the letter for the ans to his next question. CBSA OFFICER (CONT’D) And you'll be staying at the Queen’s Motel in Hearst, Ontario?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. The officer hands Zev back the letter.

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: How long will you be in Canada?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: A couple nights. The officer signs off on the card.

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: Passport. Zev reaches into the toiletry bag and pulls out his passp He hands it to the officer who looks it over; it only tak moment for his expression to change. CBSA OFFICER (CONT’D) Sir, your passport’s expired.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: It is?

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: It expired in 2002. (beat) Do you have a driver’s license?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes of course. Zev reaches into his toiletry bag again but can’t find wh he’s looking for. He dumps out the contents: toothbrush, toothpaste and razor. No gun. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 44 45 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The people waiting behind Zev grow impatient as Zev pats pants’ pockets and finally pulls his WALLET out.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here it is. Zev opens his wallet and hands his license to the officer

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. The officer stands up and walks over to his SUPERVISOR. T men huddle and steal glances toward Zev. After a long, te few moments, the officer returns. CBSA OFFICER (CONT’D) Alright, you're good to go. But, sir, renew your passport.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I didn’t think I’d need to at my age. The two exchange smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CBSA OFFICER
dialogues.text: Have fun with your friend. Zev thanks him and walks toward the exit. CBSA OFFICER (CONT’D) (to the next traveler) Declaration card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev gets back on the bus, holding the letter, and walks d the aisle. He finds his seat which is marked with his fol blazer. As discreetly as he can, he removes the Glock fro the blazer and places it back in the toiletry bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brick nursing home sits in the middle of a small, picturesque campus. Sprinklers water the shrubs and flowe arrangements. An ONTARIO TAXI pulls up to the front doors. Zev gets out the backseat, holding his toiletry bag. 35  46 47 48 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev shuffles up to a few NURSES at the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: How can I help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Can you tell me which room Rudy Kurlander is in? The nurse looks at a chart and scans for Kurlander's name

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Kurlander. Yes, Kurlander. He’s in room 238. Just go down this hallway and take the elevators at the end. When you exit the elevator make a left and then your first right. 238 will be on your left. Zev stares at the nurse -- blanks in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you get that? Zev shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t I just show you where your friend’s room is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev walks down the hallway with the nurse. Between the white walls, the shiny tiled floor, the fluorescent light the nurses’ uniforms, and the sunshine pouring in through the windows, this place couldn’t be brighter. Zev’s black toiletry bag is the darkest object, drawing all eyes to i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing in the doorway, the nurse motions for Zev to go inside. Zev gives her a thankful nod and then watches as she disappears down the hall. After wiping away some swea on his forehead, Zev enters the room. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 37

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There are TWO MEN lying in separate beds. Both look like they’re at the end of life. Zev approaches the first.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Are you Rudy Kurlander? The man stares at Zev, confused. Zev speaks louder.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you Rudy Kurlander? The man shakes his head; it could be a yes or a no.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY KURLANDER
dialogues.text: (barely a whisper) Here. Zev looks at the other bed where RUDY KURLANDER #2, 90s, skin and bones, motions with his shaky pointer finger for Zev to come closer. Zev grabs the bunched up curtain next to the wall and glides it along the ceiling track, dividing the room.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: You are Rudy Kurlander? Rudy Kurlander #2 gives a barely perceptible nod. To say is weak would be a gigantic understatement; this man is alive on pure will. Zev firmly takes Rudy’s face in his hands and studies his features. Rudy’s eyes are bloodshot and glassy; his catar have rendered him practically blind. His cheek bones near protrude through his skin. His head is covered in coarse wisps of hair. In a word, he is HELPLESS.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you German?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY KURLANDER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Were you at Auschwitz? Rudy takes a deep breath, disturbed by the question.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY KURLANDER
dialogues.text: Yes. Rudy’s eyes start to well up. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 38

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I was in Auschwitz. (beat) My whole family was murdered in Auschwitz.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY KURLANDER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: You are sorry? Rudy nods, sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you did is not something you can apologize for. Zev opens his toiletry bag and takes out the Glock.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I swore I would kill the man responsible for the death of my family. Zev puts the gun up to Rudy’s head and fingers the trigge With all his strength, Rudy lifts his left arm over his face to show his blue CONCENTRATION CAMP NUMBER TATTOO. Zev puts down the gun.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are not a Nazi? Rudy shakes his head and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: RUDY KURLANDER
dialogues.text: Homosexual. Zev processes this. He was about to kill a victim, not a monster.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I am sorry. Zev starts to cry and buries his head in Rudy’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am sorry. I am so sorry. Rudy’s fingers find Zev’s head and gently strokes his hai (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 49 50 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 39

dialogues.speaker: RUDY KURLANDER
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev shuffles down the hallway. A PIANO plays in the background. Zev’s ear picks up the music and he changes course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD WOMAN plays the piano by herself. Her fingers glid over the keys with the ease of decades of practice. Zev sits on the bench next to the woman and watches with admiration. The woman pays Zev no heed until she finishes concerto.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Moszkowski.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: You know Moszkowski? Nobody knows Moszkowski anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: My piano teacher used to say that the three greatest composers were Mendelssohn, Meyerbeer and Moszkowski. (laughs to himself) But he was biased. He was a Jew. Amazing that Zev can remember something so specific from youth but he can’t remember what he ate for dinner the ni before.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Do you still play? Zev thinks this over for a second.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Well, why don’t you give it a try? The woman slides over, allowing Zev to take the middle of bench. He flexes his arthritic fingers, closes his eyes a visualizes his music catalogue. He then slowly begins to Moszkowski’s Piano Concerto, Second Movement. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 51 52 53 54 55 56 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 40

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY
dialogues.text: We watch as Zev feels his way through the music.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Zev plays the piece carefully but accurately. The woman's head begins to lightly sway with the music. They’ve both transported to another place and time. OLD WOMAN (CONT’D) Beautiful. (beat) Very beautiful. Zev's fingers dance across the keys. His soul is waltzing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus cruises west on the Trans-Canada Highway through Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev changes buses, guided by the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev stares out the window, taking in the beauty of the north. He watches FARMERS on tractors, COWS pasturing and valleys turning into mountain ranges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus joins the traffic at the Coutts-Sweetgrass border Through the window we can see Zev taking off his blazer. worked once, it’1l work again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus travels south through Montana, passing Great Fall Helena and Butte...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev reads the letter for the thousandth time. After a bea he glances out the window at COWBOYS riding BRONCOS.  57 58 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 41

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus passes in the foreground, a minute spec set again the ROCKY MOUNTAINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev enters the hotel lobby. The RECEPTIONIST, cheerful on verge of annoyance, gives a big warm smile.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Hi! Welcome to Boise.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Do you have a reservation?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. The last name is Guttman. G-U- T-T-M-A-N. The receptionist types in Zev’s name.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Queen bed, non smoking. And I have a note here that you’1ll be needing a taxi tomorrow at 8 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. That is right.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Well, our complimentary breakfast starts at 6 A.M. so, if you want to fill up before you hit the road, we'll have plenty to eat. The receptionist hands Zev his room key. RECEPTIONIST (CONT’D) If there’s anything else we can do for you, please let us know.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: There is one thing. (slightly embarrassed) I forgot to pack extra clothes. The receptionist smiles at Zev. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 59 60 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 42

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: We can help you out with that. Our downtown shuttle leaves every hour on the hour and makes a stop at the mall on North Milwaukee street. I’m sure you can find whatever you need there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev, still holding his toiletry bag, stands at the intersection of two perpendicular, glimmering white aisle viewed from above it would look like he was the nail in t center of a large, shiny crucifix. He looks around, trying to navigate the store. He begins walk forward, following the aisle like a runway. He passe the automotive section, then appliances, then wanders thr women’s lingerie and into electronics where he approaches KEYBOARD and gently brushes his fingers over the keys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev stands in the men’s clothing section, looking at butt down shirts. A WORKER, 20s, eager to help, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: WORKER
dialogues.text: Can I help you find anything?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I’m looking for a new shirt.

dialogues.speaker: WORKER
dialogues.text: Well, we're having a great sale on short-sleeve button downs. Want me to show you?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you. The worker leads Zev to the sales rack.

dialogues.speaker: WORKER
dialogues.text: You can always get the best deals at the end of the season. The worker gives Zev a big, friendly smile.  61 62 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 43 INT. DEPARTMENT —- CHECK OUT - DAY - LATER 61 A BLACK SHORT-SLEEVE BUTTON DOWN SHIRT, KHAKI PANTS, a pa of WHITE BRIEFS and SOCKS slowly travel down a CASHIER’S conveyor belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev exits the store, holding a PLASTIC BAG. As he passes magnetic anti-shoplifting detectors, the ALARM SOUNDS. Ze pays it no heed and continues to walk through the automat sliding doors. He only gets a few feet outside before a SECURITY GUARD, 30s, overweight, catches up to him.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. You set off the alarm. I need to check your bag.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Do I look like a thief?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: It’s not my job to say who does and doesn’t look like a shoplifter. It’s just my job to check anyone who sets off the alarm. The security guard looks into the bag, pulls out the rece and verifies the purchases. He then finds a SECURITY TAG Zev's new shirt... SECURITY GUARD (CONT’D) There’s the culprit. The security guard uses a tool to take off the tag. SECURITY GUARD (CONT’D) (re: toiletry bag) I’m still gonna need to look in your other bag too, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: It just has my toiletries.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Then it won’t be a problem. Zev opens the toiletry bag. The security guard looks insi and sees the Glock. He looks at Zev quizzically. SECURITY GUARD (CONT’D) Is that a Glock? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 62 CONTINUED: 7“ 62 Zev sheepishly nods, ready for a problem. SECURITY GUARD (CONT’D) That brings back memories. That was my first gun. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 63 64 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 44

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for bringing it into the store.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: No need to apologize. You can never be too careful these days. The security guard zippers the bag closed for Zev. SECURITY GUARD (CONT’D) Have a good day. The security guard smiles at Zev and heads back into the store. Zev lets out a deep exhale and then walks toward t Holiday Inn complimentary shuttle van. INT. CHARLES’S HOUSE - NIGHT 63 Charles sits in front of his computer, talking on the phone. He’s tired and frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I’ve been on hold for fifteen minutes. (beat) Like I said to the last person who put me on hold, I’m looking for my father. He’s 90-years-old and he went wandering a few days ago. Has anyone been brought into the hospital-- (beat) I’ve already called the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some HOTEL GUESTS pile breakfast food onto their white ceramic plates while others wait for their bread/bagel/muffin to finish its journey on a large toast conveyor belt. Some other guests sit at tables reading the newspaper, typing on their laptop or prepping for a work meeting. TWO KIDS, full of energy, run around playing tag. Their FATHER tries to wrangle them in but it’s hopeless. Zev sits at a table, wearing his new clothing, eating toasted rye bread and drinking coffee. He reads the lette which rests on the table. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 45

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A WAITER walks around, refilling coffee mugs. He approach Zev...

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Would you like a refill?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: You’re very welcome. The waiter starts to pour the coffee in Zev’s mug.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Can you tell me how far Bruneau is from here?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I’ve never actually been to Bruneau but it’s in Owyhee county so I'd say it should probably take you about thirty, forty minutes or so. (beat) Watcha doing in Bruneau?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I’m going to see someone.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you have a nice trip. I heard it’s beautiful country down there -- jeez! The two kids playing tag run by and BUMP the waiter, who accidentally SPILLS SOME COFFEE ON THE TABLE -- THERE’S A

dialogues.speaker: WAITER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry! I got coffee on your letter. The waiter takes a napkin and tries to soak up the spill, making it worse.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Oh Gott. Oh Gott. Please be careful!!! You are ruining my letter!!! Everyone turns to Zev who is shouting, causing a scene. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 65 66 67 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 46

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This letter is very important!!!

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop! Let me do it. You are ruining it! Zev sponges up the coffee and does the best he can to sav the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev blow-dries the paper; there’s coffee stains on the pa but all the information is still legible. There’s just a or two that’s smeared and a little difficult to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev sits down at the small desk and, using his pen, trace over the words that have been smeared. He does this with steady hand and detail of a forger. He reads aloud, word word, as he traces:

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Besides - me - you - are - the - only - person - who - could - still... Zev takes a quick break and flexes his arthritic hand.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - recognize - the - face - of - the - man - who - murdered - our - families.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 67
dialogues.text: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 68 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls into the driveway of a run-down house. The paint is chipped, the grass is overgrown and giant piles dog shit are scattered in the front yard like land mines. The house is on the outskirts of town with no neighbors i sight. Zev gets out of the taxi and walks to the front door, carrying the plastic bag with his old clothes and toiletr bag inside of it. Before he rings the bell, a DOG STARTS BARKING. This isn’t the cute woofs of a poodle but the howls of something big and mean. The killer dog claws at the front door from the inside. This scares Zev, who stumbles a few steps back. After a moment, Zev builds up his nerve and rings the doorbell. There’s no answer except for louder barking and more agitated clawing. Zev stares at the door as the TAXI DRIVER walks up behind

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: Nobody’s home? Zev turns around and looks at the driver.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: Want me to take you somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: No. I will wait.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: I know I’m supposed to stick around but I got a couple other pick-ups this morning. The driver pulls a business card out of his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give me a call when you want me to get you. (motions at the house) Or maybe your buddy can drive you back. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 69 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 48

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: Sixty. Zev opens the envelope and pays the driver, including a t

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. Just call me if you need a ride later. The taxi driver walks back to his car and takes off. With nothing else to do, Zev takes a seat on the front steps a waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun blares down and fall’s winds blow, unhindered by the open dunes. Zev continues to sit on the front steps, reading the lett and staring at the occasional car that passes in this not so-trafficked neighborhood. The handwritten message on hi hand -- “Read Letter” -- is beginning to fade. A NORTHWEST COURIERS TRUCK pulls up in front of the house The COURIER hops out, carrying a small BOX, dodges the do shit and approaches the front door.

dialogues.speaker: COURIER
dialogues.text: ‘Morning.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Good morning. The courier drops off the box by the front door. The dog, agitated, woofs and scrapes from the inside...

dialogues.speaker: COURIER
dialogues.text: (to the dog) ‘Morning to you too, sweetie. The courier then walks back across the dung covered front grass, gets into his truck and pulls away. When the truck is out of site, Zev stands up and checks o the box. He scans for the addressee - J. Kurlander - and verification he’s at the right place. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 70 71 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 49

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With nothing but time to kill, Zev sits back down on the porch, once again angering the canine. INT. MAX’S LIVING ROOM - EVENING 70 Max sits in his wheelchair, oxygen clips in his nostrils, half watching CNN and half watching the telephone. His ai sits on the couch, a few feet away, reading a book.

dialogues.speaker: MAX'S AIDE
dialogues.text: It’s dinner time, Mr. Rosenbaum.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Bring me back -- some food.

dialogues.speaker: MAX'S AIDE
dialogues.text: Are you sure? You haven’t been out of the apartment all day.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yes. The aide shrugs it off and heads out of the room. Max doe want to leave the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev watches the sunset over the Bruneau Sand Dunes when a blue SUV, sirens on the roof, pulls into the driveway. An official Idaho state logo decal is on the front doors and “STATE POLICE” is printed above the front tires. JOHN KURLANDER, 50s, slightly overweight, steps out of th SUV wearing his State Trooper uniform, including his campaign style hat. John nearly makes it all the way up to his front door before he sees Zev.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Can I help you with something? Zev licks his lips, his mouth is completely dried out. He hasn’t had a drink since breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I’m looking for Rudy Kurlander.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You came to the right place but you're a little late. (MORE ) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 50

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My old man passed away about three months ago. Zev attempts to process this information.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You been waiting here long?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: All day. John can hear the parchedness of Zev’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: A drink would be good.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come on in. I could use another drink myself. What do you want? Beer? Water? Whiskey?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Water, please. John sees the box by the front door. He picks it up, open the front door and is greeted by his large GERMAN SHEPHER

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Did Eva miss her daddy? John bends down and pets the slobbering dog. The screen door closes behind him, with Zev still on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I am very scared of dogs.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Eva's all bark and no bite.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I’m sure that’s true but I’m very scared. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 51

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Okay, no problem. (to the dog) Sorry babe, we got company. John hangs his campaign hat on a hook, revealing a nearly bald head. He then leads the dog into a back bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calls back) Come on in. There’s nothing to be scared of now. Zev enters the house which is barren. There’s not much fo furniture except an old couch, some reclining chairs and relatively archaic television set. This is the house of someone who doesn’t spend much time at home. There’s a couple of pictures on the wall, which draw Zev’ attention. He approaches a photo and stares at RUDY KURLANDER #3, who stands with John and a TEENAGE BOY.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: That's from my kid’s high school graduation. Dad loved that picture. (beat) Here’s your water. John hands Zev a glass of water; he’s got a tumbler of WHISKEY himself. Zev takes the glass and downs it.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: When was that photo taken? Your father looks quite young. John makes himself comfortable by taking off his gun belt and placing it on the TV. He also untucks and unbuttons h uniform top, revealing the front of a sweat stained undershirt.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ‘97. My dad aged well. He always said that was one of the Kurlander's good genes. Zev finishes his water.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughing to himself) Looks like you were thirstier than Eva. (beat) You want another? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 52

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Please. And then I promise not to bother you for long. John takes the cup and heads to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s no bother at all. Stay as long as you'd like. Zev stares at the photo again, deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: (to himself) 1997.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Ever since dad died it’s been pretty lonely out here. You know, I’m out driving around all day, * doing my rounds, with nothing but the radio and the occasional dispatch. John returns with more water for Zev and more whiskey for himself; he’s a functional alcoholic. Zev takes a seat on the couch and places the plastic bag down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s nice to have someone to talk to when I get home. Eva’s great and all but she’s not much for conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: You’re not married?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Was twice. The first one took my * house, the second one left before * the quarry takes this one. That * was, hell, about seven years ago already. I wouldn't mind getting another but Bruneau ain’t exactly the best singles scene... (laughs) .».-and I ain’t exactly the best single. Zev takes a sip of water. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 53

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Did your father ever talk to you about Germany?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You kidding? He couldn’t stop talking about Germany. John takes off his boots.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Did he talk to you about the war?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Of course. (beat) You know he was a collector, right? Zev shakes his head. He doesn’t know anything.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve still got a bunch of stuff in his room. You want to see? Zev nods yes and is lead down the hall by John. 72 INT. RUDY KURLANDER #3’S BEDROOM - LATE AFTERNOON 72 John and Zev walk into the dark room.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Be careful, there’s some boxes on the floor. Let me just flip on the lamp. The bedside lamp turns on, dimly lighting the room. However, despite the light, one couldn’t miss the framed NAZI FLAG on the wall. Zev stares at the flag, heart starting to race...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was dad’s pride and joy. The dealer he bought it from swore it was flying in Berlin on November 9, 1938.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Kristallnacht. John smiles. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 54

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Dad always used to say how that flag got to witness the beginning of history. They both mull this over for very different reasons.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: What is in the boxes?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: A bunch of dad’s other prize pieces. I sold most of the collection already but these are the things he was sentimental about. I haven’t been able to let myself get rid of ‘em. (beat) You're welcome to take a look.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Thank you. John smiles at Zev. He wants him to look; he wants to sho them off. Zev sits down on the bed and opens a box. John proudly watches as Zev removes an Iron Cross and an old weathered copy of Mein Kampf.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That's a first printing. I had a guy offer me six grand for it but I couldn't part with it. (beat) I guess I’m just as sentimental as my old man. Eva starts to bark in the background.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go ahead and check out whatever you want. I’m gonna give Eva her dinner. John walks down the hallway, leaving Zev alone with the collection. Zev slowly removes a few more articles, taking each one i Walther P38, a framed map and a black and white candid ph of HIMMLER at his desk. After staring at the photo for a minute, Zev removes the final article: A WELL PRESSED SS UNIFORM. Zev holds the uniform by a hanger; his hand shakes uncontrollably. His eyes narrow at the haunting memories. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 73 REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 55

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Priceless, right? Zev, startled, looks up and sees John in the doorway. He confirmation to John’s question.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know I shouldn’t have it stuffed in a box. My dad would never forgive me. John takes the uniform and hooks the hanger on a nail, ju above a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want another drink?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Yes. That would be good.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: More water or something a little stronger?

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: Maybe something stronger.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Now you’re speaking my language. (beat) Let’s go back in the living room. This ain’t exactly the most cheery room to talk in. Zev stands up and catches his reflection in the mirror. With a small gap between the top of the uniform and mirro it look as if he were wearing the uniform. After the briefest of moments, he follows John down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev sits back down on the couch, next to the plastic bag. His mind is racing. Is the man he’s trying to kill alread dead? John walks back in with another tumbler and a half empty bottle of whiskey. He gives the tumbler to Zev and fills both their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: To Dad. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John taps Zev’s glass with his own. Zev doesn’t know whether to drink after this cheers. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMEMBER Double White Rev (08-15-14) 56

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He processes some inner thought -- probably damning the soul of the man -- and then sips his drink.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, my father was there that night.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV

dialogues.text: We are the last living survivors from our prison block. Besides me, you are the only person who could still recognize the face of the man who murdered our families. (beat) You must find Otto Wallisch.

dialogues.text: Simon Wie-sen-thal would not condone this mission. He in-sisted that all war cri-minals be given public trials. Zev nervously glances at Molly’s sleeping father, who sti little... (MORE)

dialogues.text: However, we cannot give Wall-isch that op-por-tun-ity. Even if there was enough proof, he, like us, would probably die before he could be extra-dited to Germany. We have agreed that Otto Wall-isch must die. Max's voice fades back to Molly's...

dialogues.text: You must kill him. (beat) You promised to go once Ruth died. You promised me and you promised Ruth. Molly looks up from the letter.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I need to go to the Holiday Inn at 3961 Lake Tahoe Boulevard in South Lake Tahoe.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: South Lake? That’s over an hour away.

dialogues.speaker: ZEV
dialogues.text: I have money. Zev shows the last two hundred dollar bills to the taxi driver.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: Hop in. Zev gets in and the taxi pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zev reads the letter by the faint glow of the interior do light. We can see lines drawn through the steps that have already been completed.

dialogues.text: I have planned everything for you. You must follow these steps precisely. Cross them off as you accomplish each task. Step 1: Open your closet. On the floor is your black toiletry bag. It’s already packed. Step 2: Quietly go outside the housing community at 3:00 A.M. A taxi will pick you up and bring you to Penn Station... There’s no confusion in Zev’s eyes. He is sharp and focus and knows exactly what he must do.

dialogues.text: Zev walks into the room and sits down on the bed. He continues to read the letter... INT. MAX’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 107 Max lays in bed, reading his PHOTOCOPY OF THE LETTER. Max reaches for the phone on his bedside table and rests on the pillow next to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Zev?

dialogues.text: Yes. (MORE)

dialogues.text: Thank god. (beat) Where are you?

dialogues.text: You understand -- what you must do?

dialogues.text: That’1l be $106.20. Zev opens the envelope. It’s empty. He takes out his wall and counts the money inside it...

dialogues.text: Come on in. My dad won't be up for a little while though. He’s a late riser these days. Kristen holds open the door for Zev and he enters the war house.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN

dialogues.text: Rudy slowly stands up, with the aid of a cane, and walks toward Zev. Zev stands up and faces him. They’re a mere foot apart.

RUDY KURLANDER #4 (CONT’D) Sometimes, I come out here and speak my name. (beat) I talk to myself. I remind myself of who I was. (deep exhale) Es ist der einzige Weg um zu wissen, dass ich existiert habe, bevor ich der geworden bin, der ich jetzt bin. Subtitle: “It is the only way to know I existed before wh am now.” Zev stares at Rudy, who still looks away.
